bibl.title: Letter from Howard A. Kelly to Edwin Denby, October 18, 1907

div1.p: Kelly discusses Denby's offer to initiate a pension bill for Kissinger.

div1.head: Letter from Howard A. Kelly to Edwin Denby, October 18, 1907
div1.opener:
1418 Eutaw Place
Oct. 18, 1907
Hon. Edwin Denby,
Dear Sir:
div1.p:
In a letter to me last August you were so kind
as to say that you would interest yourself in the inroduction of a bill
for a pension in the case of John R. Kissinger, who volunteered as the
subject of experiment in yellow fever.

I am anxious to take up the matter as soon as possible, for
Kissinger's health has now become so poor as to make great demands upon
his wife's time and prevent her doing as much as she has been in the habit
of doing for their support. Their immediate necessities are provided for
through the generaous subscription of last summer, but they have no provis-
ion for the future.

Our senator, Mr. Pinkney Whyte, our representative, Mr. Mudd,
and an ex senator from illinois, Mr. Mason have promised their assist-
ance in the matter, but I do not know in what way their kindness should
be utilized. Your advice and help at this juncture will be of the utmost
service.
